thank you, John Oliver -- factory farming is barbaric to everyone -- those who "live" in disgusting conditions and are then murdered, the humans who process the corpses, and the surrounding environment -- i have been vegan since around 2000?  2001? (but had already been going in the vegetarian direction since the mid-1980s) -- not only is it a crash course in what is really in your food (bc you are always reading ingredient labels), but how that food gets to your plate -- i was already involved with other issues (vivisection, high-kill "shelters," fur, etc.), and the more i learned, the more i not only wanted no part of that system, but i needed to work towards abolishing this "industry" altogether . . . i read Fast Food Nation in the mid-2000s, and there is a lot about the human cost of factory farming -- horrible injuries, abuses of workers -- and iirc, if a worker is undocumented, they are not able to get any sort of disability, workers comp., etc.  . . . more recently, through ALDF (Animal Legal Defense Fund), i learned about CAFOs (Concentrated Animal Feeding Operations), which release all sorts of toxins and pollution from massive quantities of animal waste into the water, air, soil -- the surrounding communities may be on beautiful lands, but the humans who live there (mostly poor, mostly Black and brown) suffer tremendously -- even something as simple as opening one's windows for some "fresh air" is not really possible, nor is going outside without some sort of respiratory mask

I thought I was going to have a hard time reading Gail Eisnitz' book Slaughterhouse, but as soon as I started reading, I was drawn into this "shocking story of greed, neglect, and inhumane treatment inside the U.S. meat industry." Eisnitz really does tell a story. The reader is plunged into a world it is hard to believe exists, unless, like Eisnitz, we choose to enter this terrible place, or we are forced, or feel forced, to be there. The book starts out like a novel or a movie that sets a chill in your heart in the very first scene. You enter the spiritual universe of In Cold Blood and Deliverance. Here we have it: a vulnerable woman in a world of violent men. A savvy woman courting danger, terrified, running for her life, keeping her wits, a smart chick. "Carol Taylor" is a fake name--the undercover identity of "I, Gail Eisnitz," who is boldly sneaking around in Florida chasing down a notorious animal abuser for arrest. Her search leads her to the Slaughterhouse. Years ago, when I first started learning about the things humans do to animals on farms and in laboratories, wondering if I could endure this information, Peter Singer answered my question. In Animal Liberation, he said that if the animals must go through this in reality, the least we can do is to go through it in our minds.  The Ninth Circle of Hell in Slaughterhouse is the kill floor.  Consider a horse who doesn't want to die. "'You can't spend fifteen or twenty minutes on one horse. You have to do whatever you can to get him in that box to get him skinned--fast. You can't let one horse stop you from making money.'"  (Later) "'What about the inspector?' I asked. 'Does he ever see any of this?'  "'Yes.'  "'How do you know? You've seen him?'  "'We all on the kill floor together,' he said, 'we all watching this. Sometimes he'd complain about it. But you've got a lot of guys there, new, unexperienced, and they think it's a game.'"  Pick almost any place in Slaughterhouse, and you've got testimony, an eyewitness who is soaked in blood reciting the facts, reenacting the daily ritual. Eisnitz documents alcoholism, anger, misery, murder, fear, family violence, callousness, sadism, compassion, jail time, prison sentences--the slaughterhouse milieu including the "good times." One of the book's benefits is the range of attitudes and self-revelations elicited by Eisnitz. It reminds me of what a student of mine once said about an essay we were reading: "The author said that he wasn't commenting, merely stating facts. However, his facts were full of comments."  For me, the heart of the book is the interview with Ed Van Winkle, a pig-sticker described by men who have worked with him as "the most ferocious of the stickers." He says, "'The worst thing, worse than the physical danger, is the emotional toll. If you work in that stick pit for any period of time, you develop an attitude that lets you kill things but doesn't let you care. You may look a hog in the eye that's walking around down in the blood pit with you and think, God, that really isn't a bad-looking animal. You may want to pet it. Pigs down on the kill floor have come up and nuzzled me like a puppy. Two minutes later I had to kill them--beat them to death with a pipe. I can't care.'"  The book focuses on mammals, rather than on the birds who make up the 95 percent of animals slaughtered for food. (While 35 million cattle are slaughtered each year in the United States, 35 million chickens are slaughtered every day.) However, Slaughterhouse does provide a lot of information about the poultry industry, as in these comments by inspectors Macias and Carney:  "'Poultry is exempt from coverage under the Humane Slaughter Act, right?' I asked.  "'Correct,' Carney said. 'It's not humanely slaughtered. Because they're going into the scald tanks still alive, breathing and sucking in the water.'  "Macias nodded. 'Most of them are still alive when they go into that tank and they fill their lungs. That's a reason for the high contamination.'  "'The kicker,' Carney said, 'is that when that chicken is exported to Canada, inspectors have to sign off on an export certificate that says it's been humanely slaughtered. We have no control over how they're slaughtered. None whatsoever.'  The point is that "laws" or no laws, mammals and birds alike are tortured to death and anything goes in this environment. There's a kind of macabre humor in the way the cast of characters either couldn't care less about, cannot implement, and often is not even aware of the federal "humane slaughter" law for livestock. In any case, "violations of the Humane Slaughter Act carry no penalties at all."  In trying to do justice to Slaughterhouse, I find I can't. There is too much packed into it and the book's sensibility must be experienced directly. There is Eisnitz's cancer while she is doing her investigations, her ordeals with the news media, violent sickness and death from food poisoning, information about the Clinton Administration, and information like this: "'Fat- reduced beef isn't meat,' he [a former USDA inspector] explained. 'It's fatty tissue, the solid part of fat. It's a gray, ugly mass. It makes you sick to look at it. They form it into patties, color it, freeze it--if you leave it out too long it will start to smell--and then they tell you to cook it.'"  Many animals, including their heads, are skinned alive, and rotten chicken flesh is mixed with other meat and sold for baby food. Also, about a hundred individuals are ground up in every hamburger.  Slaughterhouse shows the reader what is happening, without telling us what to do. In a manner akin to the archetype of the Ancient Mariner, Eisnitz has journeyed through hell, "And now I am telling the world." If, vicariously, we could "become" these animals, the workers, and Eisnitz herself, perhaps history would stop repeating itself.  About the Author: Gail A. Eisnitz is a cruelty investigator for the Humane Farming Association, San Francisco, CA. What started out, with a single complaint about a Florida slaughterhouse turned into a tale of intrigue and suspense as investigator Gail A. Eisnitz unearthed more startling information about the meat and poultry Americans consume. This shocking story follows Eisnitz as she becomes submerged in a slaughterhouse subculture, venturing deeper and deeper into the lives of the workers.  As the stakes become higher in her David-and-Goliath-type battle, this determined young woman finds herself courageously taking on one of America's most powerful industries. Slaughterhouse takes readers on a frightening but true journey from one slaughterhouse to another throughout the country. Along the way we encounter example after example of mistreated animals...intolerable working conditions...lax standards...the slow, painful deaths of children killed as a result of eating contaminated meat...the author's battle with the major television networks...and a dangerously corrupt federal agency that chooses to do nothing rather than risk the wrath of agribusiness...before the whole affair is blown wide open in this powerful expose.  In an effort to understand how such rampant violations could occur right under the noses of U. S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) inspectors - the individuals charged with enforcing humane regulations in slaughterhouses - Eisnitz examines the inspectors' track record for enforcing meat and poultry safety regulations, their primary responsibility. Following a long paper trail, she learns that contaminated meat and poultry are pouring out of federally inspected slaughterhouses and, not surprisingly, deaths from foodborne illness have quadrupled in the United States in the lastfifteen years. Determined to tell the whole story, Eisnitz then examines the physical price paid by employees working in one of America's most dangerous industries. In addition to suffering disfiguring injuries and crippling repetitive motion disorders, employees describe tyrannical working conditions in which grievances are met with severe reprisals or dismissals.  Reviewed by: Karen Davis, UPC United Poultry Concerns all-creatures.org/book/r-slaughterhouse.html

What solutions are there for changing how companies and corporations are fined for worker deaths? I'm sure we start getting into utilitarian territory when we start to think about what the value of a life is, so things can get gray and arbitrary.   I have seen in the comments how Finland fines parking violators on a percentage basis as opposed to one of lump sums. Germany implements a ramp-up policy where the fine increases as the number of days an employee can't work increases; the slope here is variable depending on the situation (or something similar to this policy).  From looking at it first hand, percentages seem to be the way to go. The more money you make, an hence the more power you accumulate, the harder the fall, more responsibilities there are, and more money you have to cough up. The problem here arises when you look at monopolistic industries where 1 company dominates the landscape, as well as the specific type of industry. What comes to mind are electric utilities. Depending on the scale of the catastrophe, the utility might be fined so hard that in order to stay afloat, they need to lay workers off, cut back which regions/communities have electricity at all, and/or overcharge their customers to make up for the fine.  A better system might not be a blanket percentage fine on a company's earning, but possibly something where the percentage is variable between lowest and highest level employees. Think if a company is fined, the majority of the money to pay that fine comes from the CEO, then the next highest comes from CTOs/CFOs/COOs/etc., then business managers, department managers, project leaders, expert employees, intermediate employees, and novice employees. You'd have to figure out how to factor in merit at this point too, since the younger/less experienced worker tends to make the most failures. This solution definitely isn't perfect if I start thinking about merit.   Food for though! Take care guys âœŒï¸

In Australia OHS issues are raised at a monthly meeting with management representatives and are minuted. Ohs representatives conduct hazard identification and risk assessments. If an OHS representative deems a machine or work practice unsafe they have the power to issue the company with a PIN notice (provisional improvement notice) which gives the company 2 weeks to rectify the problem or that machine or work practice is shut down.  If an OHS  rep deems a work practice or machine poses an immediate risk they can shut it down immediately. In both of those instances the OHS representative is required to inform the governing body (WorkSafe) immediately.  As for the practice of preventing employees using the toilet, an employer would have WorkSafe all over them if they even tried that. America needs to toughen up their Labor laws.

I worked for years at a meat plant.  It was mind boggling to say the least.   Whenever the line was inspected, it would be slowed down, sometimes by more than half the usual speed.    If you were injured during the job, they were very accommodating - unless you took any amount of time to get better.   The 'light duty' jobs offered were laughably bad, tone deaf, or just blind to the workers actual restrictions.   The nurse on site, who hadn't examined me in months, refuted the findings of physiotherapists - because she was a nurse, and they were a physiotherapist.   This is also the same place where someone died on the job, and they only found out when they went to yell at him for slacking off.  I tried my best to make changes, in the end - I'd ended up with an inner ear infection, and then laid off when the larger company that had bought them did some close-up corporate magic to be able to let go almost half the unionised work force.   I talked about this with someone who was currently still employed by the business, and everything I said rang true to them. More than a decade after I left.

In all fairness to a tiny part of the piece, feeling like machine SOME of the time isn't necessarily bad.  It sort of comes with repeatitive, fast-paced work, which is inherent to factories (which aren't going away anytime soon--at least not globally).  I work in an electrical assembly plant and while it sucked at first, you do get somewhat used to it.  Saying that, small things like music and talking to your neighbours can really help.  It's also important to consider how heavily the rate is enforced and how considerate are those enforcing it.  I'd also be curious to learn how often these lines break down given that they don't look staggered, and therefore one machine malfunctioning could stop the whole line and therefore give workers a small, but unpredictable break. Of course, the rest of the piece still stands.
If you just added one more person to the production line, they could take over for person 1 while they take a 15 minute break, then when person 1 gets back, they give person 2 a 15 minute break, and so on, so there is always 1 person on 15 minute break. So to take away breaks for everybody, they're saving the cost of one employee.

Why is it even remotely legal for an employer to *have* a bathroom policy, let alone a draconian one? In trade work, our rule is we go when we fucking need to, and the boss and go fuck a drill-press if he thinks we're not going to, and they, realizing they won't have workers otherwise, accept it. In some shops the bathroom is pretty gross, but it's there, and if there isn't, the boss can expect a well pissed on car. What I'm getting at is that the average worker in the US has less rights than a low-skill trades worker in other countries, and the US has judge's that decree that workers have an obligation (a *fucking obligation*, not the ability to choose to be an idiot) to die on their companies behalf.  Edit: Yeah, about those fixed fines? Those were designed that way because it was a given that they'd become hopelessly obsolete, and the corporations were well aware that the US political system is so fucking dysfunctional that no real updates would be forthcoming. While ~4k was once a not insignificant amount of money, even to a fairly large corporation, it is now less than nothing to one. This is also why I hate using fixed fines in the legal system, all fines need to be based on the party involveds ability to pay. If a multi-billion dollar corporation has an fuck up that was preventable and shows an astounding lack of empathy to have allowed, the actual management involved in the decision making process, as well as the company, need to face consequences, and since they won't be sent to actual prison ever (they'll at best be sent to the prison where you get to meditate all day, not actual prison). If a trillion dollar corporation has a million dollar fine, they are literally going to be laughing about it, make that fine in the billions and they *might* notice.

Itâ€™s so weird as a Canadian who worked in a unionized pork plant to see just how horrible American plants can be. All of the issues brought up were focused on and solved.  Knife injuries? You have a solid plastic wrist guard, anti cut gloves, chain mail gloves, a big chunk of leather called a belly guard, and depending on the area a plated belly guard. These were provided by the company to everyone in a position that could encounter those certain dangers.  Work load and bathroom breaks? Sure some days you were behind and you had to bust ass and wait it out for a coffee break to pee, but most of the time you could rely on a Formanâ€™s aid to cover for you, or a union rep to jump on and cover for a minute you needed to pee.  Physical stress and injury? Oh boy we had those. I slipped on ice and broke my shoulder. Everyone had boot allowances once a year, and if you forgot them you were provided a pair of pretty good quality rubber non stick boots. They wernt the most comfortable, but they got you to your next pay check to buy your own. Our on site nurses didnâ€™t bother giving muscle cream, they just had some giant pumps for them outside the office. If you felt you needed it, they had it. Wow, talk about timely...   I was just offered a job at a local chicken processing plant as an occupational nurse. I can understand the frustration of the employees thinking we really can't do anything to help them and they are correct. All we are legally allowed to do is basic first aid (bandaids and Tylenol) and refer them to the weekly on-site doctor for chronic conditions. Obviously if there is an urgent situation we are the first ones to respond and have to call 911.   I would also be in charge of worker's comp claims, being told that I have to "weed out the fakers since no one really wants to do this job." Yeah, no shit. It's cold, wet, and they are constantly covered in chicken parts. Plus I got that casual racism vibe that's unfortunately very common down here in the deep South, as most of the workers are either minorities and ex-cons.   Definitely a lot to consider before I accept the offer.

In Germany we do not employ those workers. Instead they are self-employed. They have to rent the equipment from the slaughter house, life in together with other workers in the same room, and do not get health insurance (which would have been necessary if they were employed, as this is mandatory in Germany). As no German would work under these conditions, these workers come from eastern European countries which are associated with or part of the EU. If they get sick, they are send back home.

Corporate fines should always be assayed as a percentage of total company revenue. The minimum fine for a non-accidental violation of a law or rule should be 1% and the maximum should be 100%. Certain types of violation should come with a mandatory minimum level of fine. For example if they cause a fatality through a previously known but not fixed safety hazard they should have to pay 10% of revenue or a hundred thousand dollars, whichever is greater. If they expose a bunch of employees to known chemical hazards without informing them or providing them with safety equipment and they get seriously sick; 50% or a million, whichever hurts the CEOs bonuses the most.  Oh, and the should be a law in place that no company executive can get a bonus in a year where the company has been fined a percentage of their revenue. There was a liquid nitrogen leak at a poultry plant in Gainesville, GA, earlier this year. It killed six people, but a lot of the immigrant workers didn't seek medical help. In fact, they fled the site for fear of deportation. This plant, though, had received 12 OSHA violations in 2015 alone (including two employees losing fingers), and more all the way up to 2020. Ive worked in Poultry plants for 6 years now and you really only scratched the surface on how bad it is for most of the workers and how little USDA and OSHA can do inside the plant. Ive seen coworkers have fingers ripped off by machines, feet crushed by pallet jacks, people faint on line and watch the supervisors restart the line before they radio medical for help, my first month a kid died because they wouldnt let him use his inhaler and he had an attack, a former supervisor had his skull crushed and died changing a battery for a pallet jack. Thats .... thats just injurys i can remember quickly. The USDA dose what they can but man the plant plays fast and loose with those USDA holds, if they could swap the product on hold with different "good" product while USDA was away or something they would w/o a hesitation. I could go on for hours. Id really support the idea of rebuilding the USDA and OSHA. If anyone read this far ill give you a small tip ive learned for buying chicken in the store, if you see a piece that is paler that the rest in a pack, dont buy the pack, it was probably dropped on the floor and rinsed off.

No idea about the US, but here in Germany the vast majority of workers in meat plants are bussed in from poorer European countries and are often not even paid the minimum wage. I always believed a fine should be percentage based, as this is a fairer system of fines, meaning no matter how much money you make, the fine is still reflective of the punishment.  If you fine a company 15% for an infraction then a company that makes 100k a year gets fined $15,000 while a company that makes 1mil get fined a %150,000, which makes the fine fairer across the system, regardless of the size of the business.

Unfortunately John, this isn't happening only in America. I worked at a meat company in Germany and it's just about the same. Out of all the workers on the work floor then about 95% of us were immigrants. We were payed 10.00 euros an hour for having to do over 1500 pigs in a shift. Along with that we were only 50 workers on the butchers floor. Along with that our shift hours ranged from 8 hours to starting on Friday and leaving at 2 am the next day. On the butchers floor the were about 10 of us actually somewhat qualified for the position. The other workers called us, "samurai" because of how fast we had to use our knife. On my second day, I had to give first aid to a collugue because his bicep was cut open by another in an accident, but he refused to go to the hospital in fear of loosing his job. We weren't allowed to have water with us, but once every couple of hours when a new batch of pigs were slaughtered we had to run to the water fountain, grab a quick drink, and then run back because a new line was coming in. My grandfather worked in a slaughter house during the 70s, he himself couldn't believe that it's gotten that bad.
When you consider what goes on in 1. slaughterhouses, 2. meat-packing factories and 3. fast-food restaurants, why would you put that stuff in your mouth?

The Federal government should institute a three strikes policy: first strike: serious fine (about 100x the current level), second strike: fine equal to 10% of the company's profit for the previous year, third strike: company is nationalized and administered by the government as a public service. Want to cheap out on winterizing natural gas pipes and let people freeze to death? Be prepared for your power company to become a utility provided as a public service. Want to exposed your workers to deadly pandemics while they're forced to shit into diapers because they can't leave the line to use the bathroom? Be prepared for your meatpacking plants to become public services, too.      The best part: allow the nationalized public-service companies to undercut privately-owned companies. The speed with which corporations will rat out their competitors' unsafe conditions to prevent creating a subsidized public-service competitor will be astonishing.

Although the conditions aren't as egregious as the meat plants, I recall you doing a piece on the conditions of Amazon warehouse workers. I saw a spike in appreciation and concern for grocery workers initially, and some harsh truths being spoken to Americans by people such as your fellow HBOer Bill Maher, telling his audience that there's a portion of America delivering Grub Hub without medical benefits, for gig work and low wages, and a good portion of Americans comfortably ordering the food. Unfortunately, he meandered and lost that narrative; I don't advocate pity or outrage, although the public has all the power to change things and it seems nothing's shocking anymore. Politicians, and corporations, can get away with outrageous statements and it's not only met with blank eyes and the sound of crickets, there are actually individuals agreeing with these statements. I think it's important to keep exposing people to the hardships others go through so that we can perhaps repair the thing plaguing the world most, a dearth of empathy. Working in retail, we're on our feet for 12 hour shifts frequently,  pulling 60 hour work weeks, doing physical labor, being exposed to customers in a fashion that guarantees no social distancing. I think it would be beneficial for everyone to see, or better yet, work a week's worth of shifts, to help engender empathy. And I'm fortunate that I have an automobile and a place to live, and only work my current job. I have older coworkers, working all day at my job, and picking up shifts at second or third jobs. I used to work in the canning industry in WA state. Over the course of four years i worked at a total of 7 different fruit canning companies. Only one cared about worker safety.Del monte canning company were strict about safety. If your caught running in the production area you are fired immediately. If you are caught not wearing gloves and ppe in the production area you are fired immediately. They don't screw around with workers safety and treat their workers pretty damn good. You can opt in to the teamsters union if you want but don't have to since the work is seasonal. Every other canning company i worked for (hansen's, snokist, johnson foods, Seneca to name a few) were bad to awful. None of them cared about worker safety with hansen's being the absolute worst. At that canning company they have no bathrooms, only porta pottys outside(in the winter) that do not get cleaned out until after production is over. So imagine going to the bathroom in 10 degree weather in a porta potty that hasnt been cleaned in 3 months. Plus out there all the hiring done at most jobs is through work agencies. Here is 1 cluster of ideas for rewriting the Defining Law of corporations. Itâ€™s not a 3-point plan & itâ€™s not the beginning of a 20 Point Plan â€” just some ideas to think about:  1. Prohibit corporations from owning stock in other corporations. Owning stock in other corporations enables corporations to control huge markets and shift responsibility, liability, resources, assets, & taxes back & forth among parent corporations, subsidiaries, & other members of their unholy families. By defining corporations in such a way to prohibit such ownership, much of the anti-trust regulatory law becomes unnecessary and superfluous.  2. Prohibit corporations from being able to choose when to go out of business (in legalese, no voluntary dissolution). This would prevent corporations from dissolving themselves when it came time to pay taxes, repay government loans, pay creditors, pay pensions, pay for health care, & pay for toxic cleanups.   3. Make stockholders liable for a corporationâ€™s debts. People who want to be stockholders would reallocate their resources to corporations that they knew something about, that werenâ€™t engaged in risky, toxic projects. (This would encourage local, sustainable businesses & healthy local economies. Imagine that.) These 3 measures might seem â€œunrealisticâ€ to some, but it beats the heck out of a voluntary code of conduct, or a wasted decade at a regulatory agency. All 3 of these provisions were once common features of state corporation codes. No wonder corporate apologists prefer that we hang around in the regulatory agencies with our heads spinning with parts per million & habitat conservation plans.  These 3 measures were quite effective, which is why corporation lawyers worked so hard to get rid of them. But they address only a tiny portion of what needs to be done. Hereâ€™s another cluster of ideas for ways to shape a democratic process that is about people. (The idea that corporations have â€œrightsâ€ would seem nonsensical to any but a colonized mind.)   1. No corporate participation in the democratic process.  Democracy is for & about human beings. Corporations should be prohibited from paying for any political advertisements, making any campaign contributions, or seeking to influence the democratic process in any way.   2. Corporations have no Constitutional rights. A corporation is an artificial creation set up to serve a public need, not an independent entity with intrinsic â€œrights.â€  3. Corporations should be prohibited from making any civic, charitable, or educational donations. Such donations are used to warp the entire social and economic fabric of society, & make people afraid to speak out against corporations.  These probably seem even more â€œunrealisticâ€ than the first batch. Imagine how good it is for corporate executives that we find these ideas â€œimpractical.â€ And by the way, these were all once law, too.  The final objection to be raised is that weâ€™ll never get anywhere as long as the â€œnews mediaâ€ are against us, refuse to cover our issues, and distort our views. Agreed.  But the â€œnews mediaâ€ are corporations, key players in a system of propaganda that encompasses not only television, radio, and newspapers but also the entire educational system. The â€œair wavesâ€ belong to the public.  Why have we allowed a puppet federal agency to â€œleaseâ€ the public airwaves to huge corporations? Ya wanna lock down? Lock down to a TV or radio station & make the public airwaves public again. Not for a day but for a lifetime.  Ya like boycotts? What if a regulatory agency gave a hearing & nobody came? The outcome would be the same but we wouldnâ€™t have wasted all the time & resources, nor would we have helped grant an aura of legitimacy to a sham proceeding. What could we do instead? When visiting the USA, I was wondering how cheap meat is sold. Now, I got an idea of the background. At least for part of it.
Worked as maintenance for a bacon processing plant in Ohio for the last 2 years. Just got canned in October.  This pretty much summed up the entire thing.  I have nothing against immigrants at all, but I find it really suspicious when in the middle of no where Ohio there we have a more than 60% illegal immigrant workforce (Guatemalan) .  This same company falsified SSN's for employees at one point and two even died on the job which lead to an ICE raid on 2017.  Wages for an average worker in production was $10.75 an hour, I have not worked for that low of pay since 2001.  The stress of the place was insane which pushed a LOT of guys to work 16 hr shifts or be held over (8hr shifts being stretched to 12 hrs)  to meet quotas. This in an already 6 day a week work schedule.  While the preached safety, and we had screenings and all that, the company did not permit time off with a doctors excuse. Since we had a point system (Max 6), if you missed a day for illness, you lost a point. Doctors excuse or not.  True the place was union, but when most of your work force can not read, write or even speak that solid of english, its easy for the union votes to just go with the company wanted.  As none of them wanted to bite the hand that fed them (and it has been speculated that transported them there and gave them places to live)  Then there is just the shady things like no direct deposit.  I know that does not seem like much BUT lets remember, the fastest way to get caught with a bogus SSN is to open a bank account, add to that the number of errors that happened in payroll? Yeah Im sure there was some wage theft involved from a group of people who had no where else to work were desperate to stay in the US.  It would just take like 3-4 hours of research to see the history of this place unfold.  Its name?  Freshmark. (Aka Superior brand meats)  Massillon Ohio They have 3 locations in the area, please for the love of all that is holy John, please put a spot light on them. I can offer more pointers as to what to look at and what details I know.  The only thing I feel bad about in all of this is that its one of the few employers in the area. So if they get shut down, a lot of my friends will be out of work.  But this is a matter of ethics. Holding a better standard.  And also pointing to the massive holes in Ohio labor laws being exploited.

I worked in a Cargill plant in 2010 (summer job between college years). Every thing mentioned in this video I saw within 2.5 months of working there. Most of the employees were immigrants (Somali) and the rest were locals who hated them. Management had to separate them into different sections of the factory because some of the locals were trying to stir up shit.  The speed at which we were expected to work was ridiculous. You literally were not allowed to leave the line to take a break. We received a 15 minute break every 2 hours. several minutes of which was required to get out of your protective gear, and another few just to walk across the factory floor to the break room.  In the time I worked there, one person got his arm caught in a machine and broken, one person got his hand degloved by a conveyer belt, and I had a 60 pound roll of plastic wrap fall directly onto my wrist. I thought it was broken so I went to the manager, who radioed the nurse. The nurse's response was "Well what do you expect me to do about that?"

Do not like meat industry? What you can do is use less meat, and the industry will feel every bit of it. Just to remind: 1) A good portion of cooked meat is about 80g/meal, to target to ~20g of protein per meal. 2) Avoid processed red meat. If possible, eat red meat/red meat products 700g/week (500g cooked) or less to lower your chance of intestinal cancer. 3) If you feel adventurous, try out vegan protein sources for fun on some of your meals! There's a good chance there are good ready to use beans, seitan (wheat protein) or bean products at your well equipped food markets that you'll like! If you need help, join a (unhealthy- , if possible :D ) vegan food oriented facebook group and ask/seek there (tell you want easy and quick to use alternatives for meat, or search the group to find these)! Use the enthusiasm of the vegans to help you!

Let's see - human suffering. Okay.   1. All over the world, but especially in places like Africa, most of the land and water is used to feed animals, not people. The animals are sold to wealthy Africans or exported to Europe. Children starve to death so that you can have a burger. You can stop contributing to this suffering by going vegan.   2. Anyone who lives near a factory farm or a feed lot will tell you that the stench is unbearable, it pollutes the air and the water, and is a leading killer in those communities. You can stop contributing to this by going vegan.   3. Low-wage factory-farm and slaughterhouse workers would not be working in those places if we, the consumers, didn't buy their cruel product. If we stop eating animal products, the industries will simply make something else, like pea or soy protein for meat alternatives. Ask someone who works on the factory floor of Impossible Foods or Beyond Meat if they prefer their job to working for Tyson. If you want to stop contributing to this suffering, you can do so by going vegan.   4. Almost all viruses, like Covid 19, bird flu, swine flu, etc, are zoonotic - which means they jump from animals to humans. What's more, 80% of antibiotics are given to farmed animals, not to people - leading to antibiotic-resistant bacteria. These viruses and bacteria kill millions of healthy humans every year. If you want to stop contributing to this, go vegan.   This is to say nothing of the fact that animal agriculture is one of the leading causes of all of the following - deforestation, ocean dead zones, greenhouse gases, water pollution, desertification, land usage, water usage.   Finally, even if all of the above weren't true - killing animals in any manner is abhorrent (some more so than others) - whether by shooting one with a rifle or snapping its neck in your back yard or slitting its throat in a slaughterhouse. When we see roadkill, we recoil. When we accidentally run over a cat, we feel like shit. If someone showed your kids where their chicken nuggets and bacon and eggs came from, the child would be traumatized and you would be upset at the person who showed it to them, rather than at yourself for paying for it to happen and feeding it to your kids.   Tell me again about HUMAN suffering?  You've got it all backwards - veganism is simply a return to doing what's right; leaving animals and nature alone. We can survive and thrive on locally-sourced produce.

I worked for 2 years at a Sanderson Farms production plant before COVID hit, I quit because they took literally 0 precautions when the virus hit. We had a meeting right when the pandemic started and they essentially told us that if we left the city for any reason we had to report it to them and that then we would be permanently suspended without pay until we received a negative COVID test. I quit the next day because I knew that all they did was ensure that no one would tell them if they left the city or they were sick because we're all broke fucks who need our jobs. Sad part is that I haven't been able to find a job throughout the last year so next month, I'll probably end up reapplying and going right back. To address the "quota" problem, Sanderson farms required me to hang 33 chicken thighs every minute. The quotas for the guys who worked on the full bird hang lines were much higher and was a lot more taxing. I had to cover up there 1 shift and couldn't do it for 4 hours, much less 8-12. Injuries: I injured my knee on the job and they refused to send me for the doctor or send me home for a couple of weeks. It took 2 months of me working full shifts while barely being able to walk until they finally scheduled me an MRI, they had stalled for so long that the MRI tech said there was "evidence of a recent severe MCL sprain". They stalled so long that it had already healed, even though I was continuously putting weight on it, causing more damage and pain. Also, John is right when they say they prey on groups that have to work for them. Most of my coworkers were 1 of 2 people. Either ex-cons who couldn't find full-time work anywhere else, or Mexican immigrants who were here on VISAs. Luckily, I'm not in either group so I could (and did) leave when things got bad but most of my coworkers have no other options. He's also right about OSHA. Inspectors give advanced warning for when they are showing up so we'll be told a few days before and we will have to deep clean the factory and they'll slow the lines down to make it look like we're working at a safe pace. Worst part is that right after they leave, they crank the lines up and overwork the shit out of us to make up for the lost time.

But because he is not here, and your an American now, lets go over what would have happened in your utopia.  In every relationship there are multiple sides... not just one.  In this case, the customers, the people.  You present a picture here of the companies that they are heartless... and it's of course easy to do! as you have shown.  But lets turn the other cheek and just LOOK, look at it for a moment. What would have happened...  Lets assume, these companies decided instead to furlough workers, cut production, and slow lines down to socially distance.   you're probably then cutting production capacity down by AT LEAST 1/4th. most likely 1/8th of what it was doing.  Now... that means each plant produces oh, lets go worst case. 1/8th of what it was doing... what that would mean would be...  you'd have meat supplies for the country dropping to less than 20% before the pandemic, you'd have a food shortage,   Compound this, meat packing has this problem! but so does crops in general, and anything to do with manufacturing goods from crops! like corn, beans, legumes, greens, ect... all have very similar issues to what you just said!  so lets slow them down to, oh, only by 1/4th of their current speed! lets do that to protect the workers!  Which would lead to shortages at factories, which would lead to shortages of literally every food product in every city.  There would be a run on the markets, meat, any type of meat would be out of stock, any type of food would become astronomically expensive, as production ground to a near halt  Prices would skyrocket, there would be a run on any sort of preserved foods before those ran out (cans, frozen, ect), as the prices on those went up, food banks would empty, people would begin to starve.   Any regulation would just make it worse by the way... it always does, fixing price but limiting supply is part of what caused every socialist society to collapse.   Oh and it just THEN gets worse. The hogs/chickens/steer still NEED to go to market. The fruits and veggies must be picked, packed and sent on...  You cant turn off the fact these are animals growing... just like you couldn't turn off the fact that crops grow.  When you remove the ability to process, now you're left with an overabundance of supply to process. Anyone not locked into a contract is trying to offload everything they can... so the price DROPS. on every sort of supply, everything. Farms go bankrupt as they are unable to pay their bills... Then nothing gets grown as its in the courts.  Worst of all, those things not being able to be sold off will have to be put down, so we would be seeing piles of cows put down in fields, then set ablaze, along with crops that can go unused... healthy crops, food ready to be eaten would be destroyed because there was no place to put it, transport it, or process it. It wont happen.   Which will then be filmed and sent to cities, to where the people are starving because they cant get food, because the system breaks down.   So. In your utopia, we would have, massive starvation, riots in the streets, law and order completely breaking down, our country at least entering a great depression if not causing a global depression, massive hyperinflation to destabilize the currency, potentially even breaking down the social fabric as people use any means necessary to secure food for their families, and, if we're lucky, a death toll only in the tens of millions by  the end of it... with the world forever changed and never the same.    Now you may call me ridiculous that the government would not let it get to that point. You're right. They wouldn't, and most likely would nationalize the entire industry temporarily under something like the war powers act to force production to continue. Though this arguably would reduce output, and create long term problems for the entire country, most likely extending or worsening our current economic situation.   But fortunately, we didn't have to go that far, we didn't have to get the government involved at all. Thanks to the brave men and women, those who were willing to work, and keep food on the tables, we were able to get through the worst part of this nightmare without a world shattering event. By them showing up to work everyday and working hard, in those conditions, and yes some died of it, they made all our lives better. Those individuals are heroes and need to be thought of as such. Their sacrifices must not be in vein, and we as a society need to come together after the pandemic to thank them all and think how we can repay them for their sacrifice.  So now, as your substitute father figure you obviously didn't have as a child, I'll tell you this. John, you're a moron. Now do us all a favor, sit down, shut the hell up about things you know nothing about.

OSHA has always been a bullshit joke. I worked in a lawn and garden factory that made chainsaws, weed eaters, leaf blowers, etc. right out of high school and the conditions were terrible. Testing booths where they calibrated motors were not properly ventilated and people who worked in there all day were often having to leave the booths and go get oxygen at the nurses station because of the massive amounts of exhaust from the product engines they were having to breathe making them sick. A lot of them complained of migraine headaches and developed such health issues as asthma and other lung ailments. The ventilation systems in the factory were ancient and supposedly OSHA visited the plant every year but nothing was ever done about it. I worked on the assembly line and the air guns to bolt parts together were little more than junk that constantly malfunctioned and even hurt people. There was one air gun that we nicknamed 'scatter gut' because it would lock up and suddenly whirl around and catch you right in the stomach if you were standing too close to it. I only ever lasted three weeks at a chicken plant. That's a whole other story I won't go into. Johns doing a great job with it though. None of this surprises me.

About the whole "horrific events in a country"... horrific events happen. They just do. Generally, there is no way to predict them nor prevent them. I repeat: generally.  I'm not going to give example scenarios, there are plenty already. The measure of how "great" a country is or not, is how it responds to that event in the _long term_ . After every event there is a reaction and a response. The reaction is seen in the media the following days and is usually front, face and center. The _response_ is how things have changed the following months and years. 9/11 happened and you can now see how it has altered transportation. Columbine happened and you can see how it has altered gun ownership control (has it?). Covid happened and you can see a year later how _the world_ has changed. Next year we'll have a better view of how we prepare ourselves for similar events.  If i were to guess, that would be "badly".

114 years ago, Upton Sinclair published The Jungle, describing how bad the working conditions in meatpacking facilities were. It caused such disgust and outcry that it lead to the passage of the Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906 which itself created the FDA. It wasn't until the 1970s that widespread worker protection laws became the norm with OSHA. So why the hell are we letting this happen? We have laws for shit like this.

Meat packing plants aren't the only large corporations ignoring worker safety. When I worked at an Amazon warehouse and developed tinnitus from working next to incredibly loud machines 12 hours a day during "peak season", I reported my injury to HR. They had a company affiliated physician's assistant examine me and he refused to sign off on worker's comp. Why? Because I couldn't prove that I didn't have tinnitus prior to working there - I hadn't previously gone to a hearing specialist to be tested.   Who goes to a specialist to be tested for a condition that you know you don't have?   A year later, when I became permanently disabled due to neck and back injuries caused by non-ergonomic work stations, lifting requirements, and speed requirements, I didn't even try to go through worker's comp. Amazon has more lawyers than God and their workers will never have decent working conditions unless they unionize - something that Amazon hires union-busting companies to derail.

So several years ago I needed to go to physical therapy for some misc. issues off and on for a while - at our local hospital.. While there I kept hearing in a distant office" step up, and down , now lift, and drop" . This went on for a couple of minutes.  Several times.  I then asked what was going on back there.  A physical therapist said "Oh thats the fitness exam for the local chicken plant". It is a timed test lifting a box, while bending & moving to see if the plants workers are well enough to return to work.   Basically it was there to weed out all but the most crippled from getting further help & benefits..  In her words" to see if they were faking it or not".  Its not like this was the last part of recovery, most often when a new arrival from the plant came due to a injury- this is the first test to see how hurt are they.    In other words if you could move well enough,  you weren't hurt.    Seemed like a pop quiz, most didn't see it coming.  Id say this was what the plant payed for.  Since most new little english, and had no health care.  No one thought anything of it...

I used to be a federal meat inspector in the large high speed beef slaughter establishments in SW Kansas. My plants that I inspected at  ran an average of 375-390 beef an hour. They don't treat the line inspectors any better than the plant workers. Years later, I've lost 30% of the function of my left hand that operates a node hook to check lymph nodes. My right hand, my dominant hand and my knife hand goes numb a lot. We lost federal meat inspectors to from COVID-19 and I knew one of the ones who died who inspected at Dodge City, KS. If you want to jump us for line speed, don't blame the ones who inspect on the line, blame Dr. Elizabeth Hagen and Paul Kieker, the heads of USDA FSIS. I remember in order to get through a nights kill of 2700 beef, I'd take 8 ibuprofen, 3 Adderall and that was before dinner. Before the second half, wash, rinse, repeat. I'd come home so sore that I'd scream in my sleep. My dreams were of the line. I'd work 10-11 hr days six days a week and would only bring home 1400 every two weeks. Welcome to hell. It's not just pork and poultry.

I used to work at a turkey processing plant in jasper Indiana years ago, no clue if it's still open. It was hell, and just walking to your work station could be very dangerous. You also only got one free very thin plastic apron a, one set of ear plugs they expected you to tie to your hardhat, cheap arm sleeves to protect you from knives and keep you clean, along with a number other small things that broke easily. And if you wanted to replace them before the week was up, because it was easy for these things to be damaged, you got your pay doct. They are terrible places to work, and they need to be shut down and reworked.

Your researchers need to look a little further back on Tyson, about 20 years ago their southern indiana plant laid off all of their workers for a "renovation."  They were paying these workers to much some of them were making 10 bucks an hour.  They replaced them with illegal Mexican immigrants, that they shipped up from Mexico via Semi-tractor trailer.  Do you remember the Semi-tractor trailer that the coyote abandoned leaving the 60(?) immigrants to roast to death in Texas(?)  They were apparently being sent up to work at the southern indiana Tyson plant.  Since many of the immigrants didn't know how to read or write it made their training cheaper too; since they didn't need much time with the training manuals.   Unfortunately for them, this meant they didn't know the dangers of working near the ammonia vat(old laying hens need to be soaked in ammonia to soften the meat enough for people to eat, they become the little chicken chunks in Campbell's Chicken Soups.)  They didn't know how to use the gas masks that weren't provided.  Instead they just pulled their T-shirts up and used them as makeshift masks.  That was good enough for Southern Indiana standards.  Until they passed out and fell into the vats killing them.  Of course they weren't documented American citizens, so no pesky OSHA investigations or Lawsuits for negligent homicide occurred.  They just ordered another semi full of Mexicans to replace the dead ones.

Just throwing this out there, since I see arguments about veganism in the comments:  Animals waste a considerable portion of the energy they consume from plants. They burn energy moving, breathing, pooping, etc. To my understanding, any energy you obtained from meat required 7x more plants consumed than if you just ate the plants directly. It's inefficient.  So, suppose, just in theory, we all went vegan. We would cut down the need for the vast majority of our farmland, leaving vastly more room for forests and human developments. We would cut the need for this kind of dangerous menial work (Don't ask "what will happen to the jobs"; We'll be confronting that soon enough with machines replacing us anyway). We'd end the inhumane treatment of animals, too, but sadly you probably don't care, so screw that. In general it'd lead to a more efficient society.  And for you it'd be cheaper too. Remember, you are basically buying 7x less food. Yeah, meat is cheap (the price is kept artificially low). But it can't ever be as cheap as 1/7th of its components.  Not expecting yall to go vegetarian, but... keep this stuff in mind. It benefits you.

An excerpt from "Fastfood Nation" by Eric Schlosser. Published on January 17, 2001:  Kenny Dobbins was a Monfort employee for almost sixteen years. He was born in Keokuk, Iowa, had a tough childhood and an abusive stepfather, left home at the age of thirteen, went in and out of various schools, never learned to read, did various odd jobs, and wound up at the Monfort slaughterhouse in Grand Island, Nebraska. He started working there in 1979, right after the company bought it from Swift. He was twenty-four. He worked in the shipping department at first, hauling boxes that weighed as much as 120 pounds. Kenny could handle it, though. He was a big man, muscular and six-foot-five, and nothing in his life had ever been easy.  One day Kenny heard someone yell, "Watch out!" then turned around and saw a ninety-pound box falling from an upper level of the shipping department. Kenny caught the box with one arm, but the momentum threw him against a conveyer belt, and the metal rim of the belt pierced his lower back. The company doctor bandaged Kenny's back and said the pain was just a pulled muscle. Kenny never filed for workers' comp, stayed home for a few days, then returned to work. He had a wife and three children to support. For the next few months, he was in terrible pain. "It hurt so fucking bad you wouldn't believe it," he told me. He saw another doctor, got a second opinion. The new doctor said Kenny had a pair of severely herniated disks. Kenny had back surgery, spent a month in the hospital, got sent to a pain clinic when the operation didn't work. His marriage broke up amid the stress and financial difficulty. Fourteen months after the injury, Kenny returned to the slaughterhouse. "GIVE UP AFTER BACK SURGERY? NOT KEN DOBBINS!! a Monfort newsletter proclaimed. "Ken has learned how to handle the rigors of working in a packing plant and is trying to help others do the same. Thanks, Ken, and keep up the good work."  Kenny felt a strong loyalty to Monfort. He could not read, possessed few skills other than his strength, and the company had still given him a job. When Monfort decided to reopen its Greeley plant with a nonunion workforce, Kenny volunteered to go there and help. He did not think highly of labor unions. His supervisors told him that unions had been responsible for shutting down meatpacking plants all over the country. When the UFCW tried to organize the Greeley slaughterhouse, Kenny became an active and outspoken member of an anti-union group.  At the Grand Island facility, Kenny had been restricted to light duty after his injury. But his supervisor in Greeley said that old restrictions didn't apply in this new job. Soon Kenny was doing tough, physical labor once again, wielding a knife and grabbing forty- to fifty-pound pieces of beef off a table. When the pain became unbearable, he was transferred to ground beef, then to rendering. According to a former manager at the Greeley plant, Monfort was trying to get rid of Kenny, trying to make his work so unpleasant that he'd quit. Kenny didn't realize it. "He still believes in his heart that people are honest and good," the former manager said about Kenny. "And he's wrong."  As part of the job in rendering, Kenny sometimes had to climb into gigantic blood tanks and gut bins, reach to the bottom of them with his long arms, and unclog the drains. One day he was unexpectedly called to work over the weekend. There had been a problem with Salmonella contamination. The plant needed to be disinfected, and some of the maintenance workers had refused to do it. In his street clothes, Kenny began cleaning the place, climbing into tanks, and spraying a liquid chlorine mix. Chlorine is a hazardous chemical that can be inhaled or absorbed through the skin, causing a litany of health problems. Workers who spray it need to wear protective gloves, safety goggles, a self-contained respirator, and full coveralls. Kenny's supervisor gave him a paper dust mask to wear, but it quickly dissolved. After eight hours of working with the chlorine in unventilated areas, Kenny went home and fell ill. He was rushed to the hospital and placed in an oxygen tent. His lungs had been burned by the chemicals. His body was covered in blisters. Kenny spent a month in the hospital.  Kenny eventually recovered from the overexposure to chlorine, but it left his chest feeling raw, made him susceptible to colds and sensitive to chemical aromas. He went back to work at the Greeley plant. He had remarried, didn't know what other kind of work to do, still felt loyal to the company. He was assigned to an early morning shift. He had to drive an old truck from one part of the slaughterhouse complex to another. The truck was filled with leftover scraps of meat. The headlights and the wipers didn't work. The windshield was filthy and cracked. One cold, dark morning in the middle of winter, Kenny became disoriented while driving. He stopped the truck, opened the door, got out to see where he was-and was struck by a train. It knocked his glasses off, threw him up in the air, and knocked both of his work boots off. The train was moving slowly, or he would've been killed. Kenny somehow made it back to the plant, barefoot and bleeding from deep gashes in his back and his face. He spent two weeks at the hospital, then went back to work.  One day, Kenny was in rendering and saw a worker about to stick his head into a pre-breaker machine, a device that uses hundreds of small hammers to pulverize gristle and bone into a fine powder. The worker had just turned the machine off, but Kenny knew the hammers inside were still spinning. It takes fifteen minutes for the machine to shut down completely. Kenny yelled, "Stop!" but the worker didn't hear him. And so Kenny ran across the room, grabbed the man by the seat of his pants, and pulled him away from the machine an instant before it would have pulverized him. To honor this act of bravery, Monfort gave Kenny an award for "Outstanding Achievement in CONCERN FOR FELLOW WORKERS. The award was a paper certificate, signed by his supervisor and the plant safety manager.  Kenny later broke his leg stepping into a hole in the slaughterhouse's concrete floor. On another occasion, he shattered an ankle, an injury that required surgery, and the insertion of five steel pins. Now Kenny had to wear a metal brace on one leg in order to walk, an elaborate, spring-loaded brace that cost $2,000. Standing for long periods caused him great pain. He was given a job recycling old knives at the plant. Despite his many injuries, the job required him to climb up and down three flights of narrow stairs carrying garbage bags filled with knives. In December of 1995, Kenny felt a sharp pain in his chest while lifting some boxes. He thought it was a heart attack. His union steward took him to see the nurse, who said it was just a pulled muscle and sent Kenny home. He was indeed having a massive heart attack. A friend rushed Kenny to a nearby hospital. A stent was inserted in his heart, and the doctors told Kenny that he was lucky to be alive.  While Kenny Dobbins was recuperating, Monfort fired him. Despite the fact that Kenny had been with the company for almost sixteen years, despite the fact that he was first in seniority at the Greeley plant, that he'd cleaned blood tanks with his bare hands, fought the union, done whatever the company had asked him to do, suffered injuries that would've killed weaker men, nobody from Monfort called him with the news. Nobody even bothered to write him. Kenny learned that he'd been fired when his payments to the company health insurance plan kept being returned by the post office. He called Monfort repeatedly to find out what was going on, and a sympathetic clerk in the claims office finally told Kenny that the checks were being returned because he was no longer a Monfort employee. When I asked company spokesmen to comment on the accuracy of Kenny's story, they would neither confirm nor deny any of the details.  Today Kenny is in poor health. His heart is permanently damaged. His immune system seems shot. His back hurts, his ankle hurts, and every so often he coughs up blood. He is unable to work at any job. His wife, Clara-who's half-Latina and half-Cheyenne, and looks like a younger sister of Cher's-was working as a nursing home attendant when Kenny had the heart attack. Amid the stress of his illness, she developed a serious kidney ailment. She is unemployed and recovering from a kidney transplant.  As I sat in the living room of their Greeley home, its walls decorated with paintings of wolves, Denver Broncos memorabilia, and an American flag, Kenny and Clara told me about their financial condition. After almost sixteen years on the job, Kenny did not get any pension from Monfort. The company challenged his workers' comp claim and finally agreed-three years after the initial filing-to pay him a settlement of $35,000. Fifteen percent of that money went to Kenny's lawyer, and the rest is long gone. Some months Kenny has to hock things to get money for Clara's medicine. They have two teenage children and live on Social Security payments. Kenny's health insurance, which costs more than $600 a month, is about to run out. His anger at Monfort, his feelings of betrayal, are of truly biblical proportions.  "They used me to the point where I had no body parts left to give," Kenny said, struggling to maintain his composure. "Then they just tossed me into the trash can." Once strong and powerfully built, he now walks with difficulty, tires easily, and feels useless, as though his life were over. He is forty-six years old.  A Quick Update: Kenny Dobbins passed away at the age of 58 on May 17th, 2014. Please read Fastfood Nation.

I worked at a poultry factory in Canada. It's a big country, so experiences may vary. Employees had regular rotations down the line and across departments to diversify physical movements, break the monotony, and reduce the likelihood of developing any long term injuries, there were one or two employees per department who did bathroom replacements so that each employee could go relieve themselves or just take some time off the line in addition to the breaks that were already planned, anyone could raise their hands for emergencies and be replaced immediately out of sequence. People with injuries would be referred to outside specialists and given light duty tasks that they would be comfortable doing in the meantime. Abuse of the system was minimal, with me only suspecting one person of doing so long term, and a stupid kid in the short term who magically had no problems playing hockey tournaments after work. We had independent federal inspectors on site at all times, and veterinarians to ensure no diseased animals were entering the food chain. The only bad stuff was with respect to peer pressure to not report minor injuries when working as a temporary summer contractor, with full-time employees claiming this would kill any chances of being asked back next year, or being hired in full time. Whether this was actually true, I don't know. My experience in the meat sector in my neck of the woods was overwhelmingly positive. I should also point out that by "injuries" I'm 99.99% referring to hand or wrist pain derived from repetitive movements that was caught early. Nothing crazy. People had safety shoes, Kevlar sleeves, a chainmail glove, and chainmail upper body protection and I can't recall a single stabbing incident that resulted in blood being drawn. The production rates cited at the beginning of the piece sound excessively high for a single line consisting entirely of human workers.

We had one thirty minute break for lunch. The pain was so bad most days that I literally stabbed myself in the hand more than once in order to just get a break. They truly did not care. "The nurse's office was just a room filled with bandaids and icy hot.

I had a disease, called Ulcerative Colitis for 7yrs of pure hell; which is becoming a rampantly popular north-american disease. (I wonder why!) I initially lost 30lbs and weighed 105lbs from food poisoning from a chicken caesar wrap. I was extremely sick for 5 months straight. I tried suing, but lawyers wouldn't take the case. Then, I was (what I consider falsely) diagnosed with Ulcerative colitis. I had another "flare-up" 2yrs later, but this was from drinking soda with "zero sugar" sucralose as a sweetener. My doctor told me, "you can still drink this stuff" "you have colitis, so you're going to get sick anyway." That was when I could read the situation. I knew the truth that I only got sick from what I ingested.  I found a YT channel a few years ago, High Carb Health - it opened my eyes to how bad my diet was. It's interesting to see how americans are sold on eating food so bad for you, but we ignore it and keep putting band-aids on our boo-boos. (medications) "You can't knock it if you don't try it" is what I realized after watching a few High Carb Health videos.  I had a realization & stopped eating meat, drinking coffee, soda, beer and milk all in one morning of saying, "I don't want this pain anymore. I don't want to do this anymore." I started eating 2 bananas for breakfast, asparagus & mushroom salad for lunch, potatoes for dinner. In 2 weeks it felt like I was back to full health, like as if I was never sick to begin with.  In about 3 months, I was confident enough to take myself off the $1,000/mo meds my doctor put me on; That was almost 3 years ago and I'm doing far better than when I was on the UC medication. I am mostly vegan but I still have pizza (can't avoid it living in NY), and chocolate (nutella, cookies); nobody's perfect. I watch out for what I eat; even though being skinny to begin with. (average 125lbs now)  I began making observations in my everyday life. I started looking at how people are excessive consumers. When the pandemic hit, all the meat was off the shelves out of everyone's panic; but the slightly more expensive meat alternatives were fully in stock. It was hilarious to me because it was evidence of consumerism at its finest. We're all told our whole lives that meat is healthy for us, milk 'does the body good', etc. If you put a few minutes of thought into it, you'll realize you're being sold too easily. Think for yourself. It's simple to comprehend. Maybe if you were less of a consumer, you'd do better for yourself. That's how I've grown to approach almost everything lately. Eat some apples, eat a banana from time-to-time Have an orange. See how you feel. When I used to work at FedEx as a package handler, the items would come down the line so fast that it was extremely hard to be able to take a restroom break because of the way our work space was organized. If you're the first in your line grabbing items for the first three trucks, all your items would fall into the hands of the next 6 trucks/the other 2 package handlers in your line. The turnover  rate was very high which meant we were often understaffed and sometimes had two handlers split 9 trucks. Sure you could ask your manager if they could cover for you, but not only do they have other things to do but you can't ask every time you need to take a quick wiz. I always went to the restroom before going to work and would only take breaks if I really had to go and I'm happy to say I never wore a diaper. So glad I only worked there for a little bit over a year.

I worked in manufacturing for 15 years, the treatment in the video is pretty much the same across the board. There was always a huge disparity in treatment, expectation, and pay between line workers and office workers. I was blown away when I moved from the floor to the office (due to my degree and experience, not because of an upward mobility option) to see the difference. Even the most basic things like showing up on time was handled laxly for office workers and punished severely for line workers. The fundamental issue I saw was that line workers were viewed as an unskilled dime a dozen expendable asset where as office workers where viewed as long term investment; even though at the bottom, both were entry level and just as replaceable. I ended up being able to leave for a better career in education, but many don't have that ability and due to their backgrounds; many take the horrible treatment and say "at least I have a job".

Where I'm from in NE Kansas, we have at least... 5 or 6 plants/warehouses to get a job at. All in probably a 100 mile area. I worked at a Smithfield plant in my hometown. It's got good benefits, the least terrible of the terrible shift based hours, and kind of good pay. I worked overnight from 6pm-6am. The working conditions were safe, but that's also only because we were a packaging and processing plant. We weren't a slaughtering facility. I was getting early signs of carpel tunnel a week into working there, they did have free physical therapy sessions for people suffering from work related pain though. It's no joke and like I know for some communities, like mine, if you aren't in the military or have a college degree, this is the only job opportunity that they have to support their family.

The production lines are not going to slow down unless there is a paradigm shift in how work performance is measured.  It is very easy to show job performance by counting how many cases came off the line at the end of the day and if that line met that day's schedule.  It's an easy number that makes the CEO, CFO, and the management teams look good on paper no matter the living hell that those on the production line have to go through in order to achieve it. This share of the mass of work for OSHA just highlights an event in my life as even more idiotic.  I worked in a toxicology lab, and one of my coworkers filed a bogus workplace safety claim.  So for two weeks, we had an OSHA guy in our lab, watching and documenting everything we did.  He found absolutely nothing wrong except that we didn't have a guide on how not to be stupid in a lab (so we got a tiny fine for that).  After that bogus claim was shot down, the (now former) employee then turned around and filed a discrimination claim (the individual had quit the position, stating they didn't feel safe, despite all tests proving there was no hazard) - again with OSHA.  So another week was taken up by meetings with a board of three individuals from OSHA questioning a bunch of people from managers, to our CEO, to myself (as the in-the-trenches coworker of the claimant).  I can't even imagine how many actual problems they could be investigating if those 4 people didn't have 3 weeks wasted on just this 1 person making false claims.
It's sad to remember all the shocking info I discover from LWT videos and then realize how normal and common knowledge this video's information is in the Midwest, where I live. Like we've been desensitized to the abuse from the plants around here and we've come to expect it.

Man, has this industry changed. I worked a year at a family owned meat packing plant in Michigan to make money for school. The work was not easy even in 1982, but they treated us pretty well and paid pretty well. We got regular breaks, and when I did start developing a repetitive stress injury, they sent me to a doctor and moved me to a different, less physically strenuous job. And we never crammed workers together on the lines. JBS owns them now, and in 1994, there was an indictment - they had brought in a new human resources person - a Mexican immigrant, who had connections to bring in illegal workers, and provide them false documents, so the company could save money on pay and rising cost of benefits - which the illegals did not get, of course.

Big or small. ALL meatpacking companies do this. The one in our small town (5,000 people maybe) deliberately employees anyone with a criminal record and then cuts their pay compared to grocery or major plant meatpacking pay. They know this is the only place that will hire them for a dime more than min wage. No protections. No sick pay. Mandatory 6 days a  week rotating 10-12 hour shifts. If you dare take a day off for anything (a funeral) you're demanded to work your next Saturday 'off'. When I was getting tested for COVID my husband's employer refused to let him quarantine. They literally said, 'We're not paying for you if you have COVID." There's a man who's worked there for decades going blind because of the bacteria in the meat (they slaughter in house too, not just processing) and he's getting NOTHING from this business. These guys can't afford to take off if they're sick, can never take a vacation, and when the pandemic hit the boss passed around a note that said they should be grateful they have a job and all the overtime hours he was providing them (not optional hours BTW). while it's not a bad idea for ERCOT to fall under federal regulation, it's not necessarily a good idea for us to hook it up to the national grid and activating our interconnection to the national grid would likely not fix the problem anyhow.   as you noted, the main problem is deregulation of the generators. CA's subgrid experienced similar problems when it deregulated generators in the same manner so being interconnected to either the eastern or western grid would likely not have avoided the problems caused by deregulation of the generators. being on their own grids has not stopped US states and territories outside the continental US from being regulated. we'd likely interconnect to the eastern grid on the SPP subgrid which also experienced problems during the storm (though it was delayed by a couple days and they didn't have urban areas which only had enough power to run critical infrastructure so the rolling blackouts wouldn't roll), but it's not like Biden is unaware of the interconnect and didn't consider activating it--it probably would have just caused more problems on the SPP subgrid rather than alleviating our problems. we have an interconnection to Mexico's grid which can be activated is primarily used to get power to the Rio Grande Valley and the areas on the other side of the border from it when they get hit by a hurricane. Mexico has a fully nationalized grid which is more reliant on natural gas and they had rolling blackouts in 26 states. we do a lot of green energy pilot projects on ERCOT. and, probably most importantly, there is a connection to your main story: we don't staff regulators properly at any level of government. our two nuclear plants are regulated by FERC and one of those had a reactor go down during the winter storm.   the problem is SB-7 (76-R) which was passed in 1999 and should be tossed in the trash with the exception of enabling statute for electric co-ops. the legislator you showed talking about the 2011 storm is Glenn Hegar (then a state senator, now the state's comptroller) and he actually got SB-1133 (82-R) passed that year to allow PUC to force generators to weatherize, but it conflicted with several areas of statute which were enacted under the 1999 legislation.
