Iâ€™d like to just touch upon something that was mentioned in this clip in a little bit more depth to further the point that, no, employers donâ€™t care at all. (This is pretty much a tangent.and is not to say that the rest of the points in the video are invalid or less important). Iâ€™m a workersâ€™ comp adjuster (i.e., the bad guy whose clients are not the injured workers/claimants but are the employers) who handles claims in the states of New Jersey, Maryland, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Delaware, and Texas.  I want to first point out that, in the United States, workersâ€™ compensation is a no-fault program. Very much like New Jerseyâ€™s no-fault auto-insurance, there are VERY few reasons you can still sue your employer for a work-related injury. You would not be able to file a civil suit while collecting workersâ€™ comp benefits. You can file claim petitions (this is not necessarily â€œsuingâ€) against your employer if you are on any level of workersâ€™ comp benefits OR if your claim was denied in the first place (in some states like Massachusetts, a claim petition is referred to as a form number). There are, like, almost only ever two reasons anyone would ever be fired for a workersâ€™ comp claimâ€”and even then, itâ€™s not really merely because they are collecting comp benefits (this being a functional capacity exam giving permanent light duty restrictions that cannot be accommodated long-term OR legitimate insurance fraud/defrauding workersâ€™ comp).  Now that thatâ€™s out of the wayâ€¦  A lot of the problems I encounter in my day is simply the result the worker not knowing what to do. Iâ€™ll kinda exaggerate the percentages here for simplification, but I would say that 75% of claims reported to me late are the result of not knowing to report them in the first place or not knowing who to go to for medical treatment. They donâ€™t know that they need to report prior to seeking medical treatment (in some states, sorta-kinda-maybe), and 15% of this group only finds out IF the doctorâ€™s office happens to be experienced enough in workersâ€™ compensation to have the brains to tell the injured employee to go to their employer first.  Another 10% of problems is the result of a language barrier when reporting. Workers tend to feel that they need to complete their written injury reports in English. This is not true, and no judge of compensation in any state will accept this as true either. Workers can report in whatever language they feel most comfortable; adjuster actually encourage this. Claims administrators and adjusters like me have literally no issue hiring a certified translator (we do have those). If something is not reported, then we donâ€™t accept it as part of the claim. Iâ€™ve had a few claims where, for example, someone slipped and fell. She hit her head, reported only her head, but then claims literally five weeks later that her knee was also in pain. Turns out that she hit her knee on a nearby table.  The other 15% of claims is a combination of the employer taking its sweet-ass time to report the claim to its claims administrator, the employer delaying the initial claims investigation in an incredibly desperate and outright ridiculous attempt to deny a claim that really should be accepted as compensable from the get-go, and the employerâ€™s internal issues (such as creating panels of their workersâ€™ compensation medical providers in States like Pennsylvania where that really matters).  The problem is that, at least with my employers, they are multi-location employers. One of my clients is a school district, but it has dozens of schools across a city with twelve zip codes. The other is a nursing facility with locations in five or six states. Although there is a central department overseeing workersâ€™ comp within the employersâ€™ internal organization, that still leaves it to the individual locations to do their jobs properly. Unfortunately, even if the central/corporate workersâ€™ comp department cares, the individuals at lower levels may not. And this is 100000% being overburdened with their actual jobs (such as the nursing facility with its main contacts in each respective facility having to assist with actual nursing jobs due to understaffing that has only gotten worse with covid shutdowns).  I would argue that, at the most, 1% of the claims Iâ€™ve ever had would qualify for an investigation into fraud allegations; maybe 0.00000000001% of those suspected claims ought to be prosecuted legitimately as fraud.  As such, 99.999999% of these aforementioned problems are employers unsurprisingly the result of the employerâ€™s failure to really care. Itâ€™s often the result of the employer not really educating their employees on reporting protocol and employee workersâ€™ compensation rights until their claim goes to an adjuster or giving help where it is needed so that the supervisors responsible for reporting from the individual locations can do their jobs timely.  Employers are too reactive no matter how proactive they think they are (or are proactive in the wrong areas). I may work for the employer side of workersâ€™ comp, but I have had MANY moments where I butt heads with an employer because the employer wants to do something that will bite everyone involved in their asses. Sometimes, while speaking with an employee, I really do want to tell them to get a lawyer. I feel that bad for some of them.  And even when the employee does something that ultimately benefits the employer, the employer runs with it without considering any possible consequences. My father is a butcher. There have been many days he has come home with horrible cuts that he patched up with Neosporin and a band-aid. How he has yet to lose any of his fingers from infection after almost thirty years of working at this grocery store is beyond me. He has filed only ONE workersâ€™ comp claim for a laceration due to the excessive bleeding and discoloration (which was most probably the result of him being on blood thinners). He went to only the ER and decided to remove the sutures himself, and not once did his employer tell him to keep going for treatment. Yes, you canâ€™t force anyone to go to the doctor. However, it goes to show how heartless employers can be by not at least mandating the employee (my dad in this case) go to a work comp doctor to ensure that there is no infection from how he removed his own sutures.  Meanwhile, I always hear every employer that I work with bitch and moan about costs.  â€œEmma, what do you think our exposure on this claim is?â€ Instead of asking me this, have you tried reaching out to the dude/dudette and ask how theyâ€™re doing? Because youâ€”the employerâ€”can save a lot in medical costs and litigation costs just by being a person to another person.

I saw someone post that our generation needs a new Upton Sinclair to write a new "The Jungle."  Sadly, people already do.  Books and documentaries as earth-shakingly revealing as "The Jungle" are released all the time.  Unfortunately, the wealthy and elites today live in a society that does all their work of shutting it down for them, by drowning it out in an avalanche of entertainment.  Game-changing books like "Uncle Tom's Cabin" or "The Jungle" came out during a time when everyone literate read books.  They processed information and ideas thoroughly, one source at a time, with nothing else to distract them, not even radio for background noise.  If something outstanding was published in the pre-internet (or even pre-TV, or pre-radio) days, it had the power to change the world.  But today?  Nothing stands a chance.  Jesus could return or aliens could land or zombies could rise from the grave, and if any of them wrote a book, most people would never even know it existed, much less read it, on their way to click on the next YouTube video. 6:50 Carpal Tunnel Syndrome is not a repetitive stress injury -- it's a congenital condition. I don't doubt that the repetitive work in a meat-packing plant can exacerbate symptoms of carpal tunnel, or cause it to progress faster than it would in workers in another field, but it won't *give* anyone carpal tunnel as the weight of current medical evidence indicates that carpal tunnel *is not caused by repetitive strain*. Work-related carpal tunnel is, according to current assessments, not a condition of causality -- i.e.: the work does not cause the condition -- but one of severity. Almost universally, those who show work-related symptoms would have developed carpal tunnel syndrome at some point in their lives, and the distinction between actual CTS and other, more common wrist/hand injuries like tendonitis, strains, and sprains in research is often poor-to-nonexistent.

Proposal: When a business violates a work safety law, they're liable for every employee in the organization exposed to that risk, not just the one that falls victim to it.  So if a plant isn't up to code and a worker loses a hand, the fine isn't for the one injured worker, it's for all the employees in said plant that were also risking said injury. If an inspection discovers that safety procedures aren't being followed, the fine is multiplied by the number of employees the procedures were meant to protect. This would effectively skyrocket penalties for large consolidated workplaces with negligent management, and allow the penalties to scale correctly with the size of the business.  In addition, if fines collected are high enough in scale, this money could be used to expand OSHA and other programs. Structure the organization in a similar way to how many local police departments use collected fines to supplement their budgets. Larger fines bring in more OSHA funds which lead to more inspections and more fines, which in theory would result in an eventual equilibrium wherein OSHA attains a size proportional to the violations it can collect on.  It's still not a perfect solution, and fines are still only fines, but would certainly be worth testing, certainly a step in the right direction. Corporatize the workplace safety organization and suddenly you're fighting for-profit giants with your own for-profit giant. Settle the fight between regulation and the free market by turning the regulating body into its own competing market.

I worked at a chicken factory for exactly one month. The second day there I could barely move my wrists from the same repetitive motion for 8 hours. The line was too fast and supervisors got lippy with me for struggling to keep up. The conditions were horrible and I went home with a sore throat every night because of how cold and wet it was. My breaking point was when I started to get nauseous and have bathroom troubles and asked to go home. The supervisor said to see the nurse for him to determine if I could leave. 1:14 no Jon, they don't get talked about nearly enough. and what nearly no one wants to talk about are the emissions from the food industry. the world has set climate goals for 2050 for reaching somewhat near zero emissions and that means we need to save emissions in all sectors. everyone is talking about renewable energies and electric cars. almost no one is talking about the future of our food. depending on the source you look at, around a quarter of global emissions come from food. from those food emissions, around 50 % go back to animal agriculture (the farms, the crops for the animals and land use). around 30% of emissions go into producing crops and produce for human consumption. and yet only 17% of our globally consumed calories come from meat and dairy. meat and dairy are highly inefficient food sources, because they always use a middle-man (the animal), that needs to be bred and kept alive until slaughter/milking.  tl;dr: we have a highly inefficient food system which on it's own will prevent us from reaching the 2050 climate goals. we need to improve the way we produce food, because nowadays it is causing way too many emissions. that is the case for plants, dairy and meat. but dairy and meat are so inefficient, it doesn't matter how much we improve them. as long as those products come from living beings, they will be multiple times less efficient than plants.  sources: https://ourworldindata.org/food-ghg-emissions https://ourworldindata.org/environmental-impacts-of-food  edit: and seeing how many people in the comment section are uninformed about the subject, just shows how important it is that this topic gets covered on a big show like yours. people often don't know that the majority of soy beans in the world get produced to feed animals, not to make tofu. many people believe that grass-fed beef is a viable "greener" option, but it is actually causing way more methane-emissions than factory farming and also needs multiple planet earths to have enough space for all the animals. and people also often still think that a diet without meat and dairy is unhealthy, while we have top athletes like Tom Brady, Lewis Hamilton, Novak Djokovic, Gabriel Medina and many more on plant-based diets. it is horrifying how much misinformation is out there while the emissions from our food industry are one of the biggest challenges of our time.

The issue of fines for non-compliance with regulations being far less than the costs of compliance is widespread.  It would seem that a simple federal mandate that fines be levied in proportion to the costs of compliance might have some actual impact on companies deciding to game the system and pay the fines instead of running their business in compliance with the regulations they are supposed to be working under. For example if a factory is found to be out of compliance with safety regulations, then an independent contractor could be brought in to determine the costs of bringing the factory up to compliance.  The fine levied should be double the cost of the costs of bringing the factory up to compliance, and that fine should be applied for every single time the factory is found to be out of compliance.

The speed of production is generally pretty ridiculous in any factory that I've ever worked in.  For example, my current employer expects my line to turn out almost 90 parts in one hour.  That means that most stations on that line have seconds to complete their work and move onto the next part.  I'm not saying my job is really all that comparable to theirs but repeated stress injuries and other types of injuries are quite common due to how we work.  Also, with lack of replacement workers for people on the line and the speed of the line it is not surprising that many workers feel stuck when they need to go to the bathroom.  It is annoying having to hunt down your supervisor so you can go with the knowledge that you might come back to a mess due to no one replacing you or someone inexperienced.

Quick mathematical/political breakdown, given the numbers stated here, and from other research:   John cites it would take 165 years for OSHA inspectors to inspect every business. Checking the source, at the time, OSHA had 862 Inspectors. Mathematically,  this means that if we wanted to have enough Osha inspectors so that every business could be inspected every, say 10 years, we would need to get 16.5 times more inspectors.   Checking other records, it looks like Inspectors make up somewhere a little under half of OSHA's staff. So, logically, we'll need to increase other roles as well (training personnel, call processing, etc), but probably not QUITE as drastically. However, let's be generous, and round to an even 30x. So for every new 10 new inspectors, we also hire 8 more support staff. This is almost certainly excessive, but again, we're being generous. So we need to hire...25,000 more people, roughly. (30x862 is 25,860, minus the existing 862, for 24,998)   The average wage of an OSHA inspector, according to several sources, is around $50,000 a year. I do NOT have the data to find all the support staff, but let's increase to $55,000 for the congregate, just in case higher wages for more senior inspectors/command staff outweigh the costs of, say, receptionists, janitors, etc. This feels unlikely, but again, I don't have the data to say.   So the total increase to the budget of OSHA would be $1.375 billion a year, before things like "additional office space" and other considerations come into play. This would equate to...roughly $0.92 in additional taxes per month per US taxpayer, minus however much income they generate through additional fines.  It would not be particularly costly to fix this.

I worked for a local food chain as a meat department "butcher", they actually threatened to write me up for cleaning the meat grinder too much... according to their training and regulations, any time a new product is going to be grinded up, we needed to fully clean it to prevent cross contamination. I quit after I reported this and a few other cleaning/health issues, and was told by the stores head managers that I was to do exactly as told by the meat manager.  2nd story... quit 7-11 when they threatened to fire me for refusing to cook frozen chicken tenders: that they let thaw on a counter for 5 hours. (to this day I will never eat 7-11 cooked foods.)  Honestly I'm just ranting because I can't recall in near a dozen food based jobs... I never once got praise for tossing bad food or calling out bad practices... I just became the enemy...  (next time you are allowed in a fast food place when you get food: watch how gloves are rendered near useless almost every time... they are used to clean and cook without changing them. they are used to touch cloths and skin and not changed after... the one I see most is putting their gloves on the counters/walls/ledges between food items and not swapping them out... The best way to kill your apatite is sitting by the bathroom and noticing how often employees go in and end with a flush but no use of the sink...) so rule in fast food... ignorance is bliss...

Coming from a girl who's worked in slaughterhouses for the last 15yrs,Thank you for this story. We work in terrible conditions, cold and wet all day with bare hands in ice and under running water. Once the leadman starts killing everyone works at breakneck speed until it's done, so that bathrm break thing doesn't surprise me. The company doesn't pay to heat the building in the VT winters. When company housing oil tank broke we were responsible for getting wood for the simple woodstove in the kitchen we depended on to heat the 8rm farmhouse from 1800s. When the water pipes busted they didn't fix it, we've been 3yrs now without water in the house. Sometimes they don't pay us and sometimes when they do, the checks bounce. A coworker got 2 fingertips ripped off in the plucker and they refused to help with his medical bills. They pay the leadman who's been there 30yrs less than $15/hr. This isn't even a corporation I worked for(finally left last yr), it's a "small family owned farm"; that's part of how they get ppl to put up with it. The owners use a combination of pretending they consider u family, making empty promises, and passive aggressive guilt-tripping to keep employees with low self-esteem working. They also refuse to pay unemployment and will fight you, I found that out when I left to avoid sexual harassment. I have a hundred horrifying examples that someday I'll expose.
